Concentrate On Subleads
Jim Oswald, director of the
Barnstormers April 27-29 production of "Once in a Lifetime," exDressed optimism over the first
month's rehearsals, saying, "UP
to this Point, we have concentrated on rehearsing the leads,
Who have attained such technical
excellence that we are now shifting over to the sub-leads."
Noting that the rehearsals are
about a week ahead of schedule,
Oswald expects that the increased
Pace will not remain constant;
however, Barnstormer President
Gordon Stick said the "rehearsals
are inspirational and full of great
laughs—they are going great
guns."
The story concerns "the turlri°11 of Hollywood during the first
days of talking films. In keeping
With the tradition of this period,
Costumes and characterizations
Will follow very closely the mannerisms of the late 1920's," OsWald said.
He added that "Shows about
the 1920's, such as 'The Vamp'
and 'The Boy Friend,' have proven
Popular during recent years. The
Barnstormers will ape though,
not imitate, (these productions)."
"A trio of vaudeville actors in
New York City decided to go to
Hollywood during the early days
Of the Talkies to set up a school
of elocution—this is the basic

Basil Papadakis, of Georgetown
University, will speak on "The
Modern Greek Theater" at a Playshop-sponsored drama evening,

believes that this group is "unique
in the country." The organization
